avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind and new snow: The avalanche danger will already exist in the early morning. Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for restraint.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate wind from westerly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. These can be released, even by a single winter sport participant, in particular on very steep slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep slopes at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation a large number of dry and moist avalanches are to be expected in the afternoon, even medium-sized ones.

snowpackStructure.comment:
In some localities 10 to 15 cm of snow, but less in some localities, fell in the last few days. In particular along the border with France 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Thursday above approximately 1800 m. Up to 2000 m rain will fall in particular from the border to France to Valais.
Distinct weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack in all aspects.
In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2000 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. Adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions a little snow is lying.

tendency.highlights: Slight increase in danger of moist avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Be careful, many rocks hidden by fresh snow. The more recent wind slabs are small and in some cases prone to triggering.
avalancheActivity.comment:
The fresh snow of the last two days as well as local wind slabs are lying on top of a weakly bonded old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.
Wind slabs can in some places be released by people. This applies especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, especially in pass areas in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, especially on very steep slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are therefore difficult to recognise.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Over a wide area 10 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m. The southeasterly wind has transported the new snow, in particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable). 2 to 5 cm of snow will fall on Thursday above approximately 1600 m.
In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2200 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. On steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m a little snow is lying. At low and intermediate altitudes from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.

regions.name: B - VALLI DI GRESSONEY, AYAS, CHAMPORCHER

avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind and new snow: The avalanche danger will already exist in the early morning.
avalancheActivity.comment:
In isolated cases avalanches can be released in deep layers reach medium size on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes. These avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye, caution is to be exercised in areas where the snow cover is rather shallow,, this also applies in places that are protected from the wind.
In addition the rather small wind slabs of Thursday are capable of being triggered in some cases. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, in particular on very steep slopes.

snowpackStructure.comment:
15 to 20 cm of snow, but less in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m. 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Thursday above approximately 1800 m, in particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable).
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the old snowpack in all aspects.
The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.
At low and intermediate altitudes less snow than usual is lying.
Adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions a little snow is lying.

tendency.highlights: Slight increase in danger as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
